0.88}}}, 'overall_burstiness': 0, 'writing_stats': {}, 'subclass': {'ai': {}, 'human': {}, 'mixed': {}}, 'result_message': 'Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'ANCHORAGE, Alaska (KTUU) - With the arrival of yet another large snowfall — and a record-breaking milestone — municipal and state crews are once again working around the clock to clear roadways. Paul Vanlandingham, the street maintenance manager with the Municipality of Anchorage, says crews are working on the main priority roads, commonly called arterial and collector roads. The foot of “light and fluffy” snow that’s dropped since Sunday makes plowing easier, he said, compared to November’s wet and heavy snow. But this snow creates visibility problems, “especially on some of the higher speed arterials and the highways,” said Vanlandingham, who urged drivers to slow down and increase stopping distances. Vanlandingham expects plows to enter residential areas Monday night or Tuesday morning, with an expectation to have those streets finished by the weekend. Still, that timeline is dependent on how the snowstorm progresses in the coming days. Justin Shelby, with the State Department of Transportation and Public Facilities, says his crews have been out since the snow started falling over the weekend, and have had to hit the highways multiple times. “Right now our guys are staying on top of it,” he said. “We anticipate that they’re going to be able to continue to stay on top of it. It is going to take several passes to get everything clear.” DOT is also focusing on clearing ramps and has called out contractors to help clear other priority roads, Shelby said. “This snow is a lot easier for our guys to handle. I think the biggest issue we’ve got right now is visibility, especially with the blowing snow and the plows traveling on the road, it’s going to be hard for them to see drivers,” he said. “So we really ask the public, ‘Don’t crowd the plow, give them 100 feet of space behind [them] and make sure they can see you.’” Shelby says DOT started up snow haul operations a couple of weeks ago but has paused those operations due to this snow. According to Alaska 511, the surface conditions in Anchorage feature icy patches and drifting snow. DOT warns motorists to be prepared for the ice on bridges and overpasses and asks drivers to reduce speeds and drive with headlights on. Check the Alaska 511 website and Alaska’s News Source traffic page for all traffic reports and road condition updates. More information about plowing, including the current status of residential areas, can be found on the municipal website. Copyright 2024 KTUU. All rights reserved.'}]

second prize is 4%; third prize is 2%; fourth prize is 1% and the remaining 85% of the raffle fund will grow the fund for future year prize money.', 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 4.286638431949541e-05, 'sentence': 'In total, five years of the PFD raffle has resulted in “$3.4 million” of education funding.', 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 4.7114663175307214e-05, 'sentence': 'Copyright 2024 KTVF.', 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 4.308486677473411e-05, 'sentence': 'All rights reserved.', 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}], 'paragraphs': [{'start_sentence_index': 0, 'num_sentences': 11, 'completely_generated_prob': 7.905466206762634e-10}], 'completely_generated_prob': 0.005050666496180035, 'class_probabilities': {'human': 0.99494933350382, 'ai': 0.005050666496180035, 'mixed': 0}, 'average_generated_prob': 0, 'predicted_class': 'human', 'confidence_score': 0.99494933350382, 'confidence_category': 'high', 'confidence_scores_raw': {'identity': {'ai': 0.005050666496180035, 'human': 0.99494933350382, 'mixed': 0}}, 'confidence_thresholds_raw': {'identity': {'ai': {'reject': 0.65, 'low': 0.75, 'medium': 0.92}, 'human': {'reject': 0.7, 'low': 0.82, 'medium': 0.92}, 'mixed': {'reject': 0.7, 'low': 0.8, 'medium': 0.88}}}, 'overall_burstiness': 0, 'writing_stats': {}, 'subclass': {'ai': {}, 'human': {}, 'mixed': {}}, 'result_message': 'Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'FAIRBANKS, Alaska (KTVF) - The winners of the fifth annual Permanent Fund Dividend Education Raffle have been announced with a total of $130,73.85 being split between multiple people. From nearly 10,000 entries, four winners were selected at random to win this years Permanent Fund Dividend Education Raffle also known as the PFD raffle. They include Deborah Main, winning $69,727.92, Vassily Zavoico receiving $34,863.96, Melanie Wahl receiving $17,431.98 and Gary Lehnhart awarded $8,715.99. The prize money making up just 25% of all the money acquired, the remaining 75% all goes to education in one way or anther. That makes for a total of $749,000. “$550,000 was raised for education,” said Adam Crum the commissioner of the Dept. of Revenue. Crum continued with the break down and said, “$499.700 will go directly to school districts, $249,800 will go to the education endowment fund for funding education in the future.” Of the raffle fund, first prize is 8% of the raffle fund; second prize is 4%; third prize is 2%; fourth prize is 1% and the remaining 85% of the raffle fund will grow the fund for future year prize money. In total, five years of the PFD raffle has resulted in “$3.4 million” of education funding. Copyright 2024 KTVF. All rights reserved.'}]
